p: Agricultural workers and others who rely on water and/or rainfall for their livelihoods are at greater risk of experiencing the mental health impacts of drought [ 46, 51, 83, 174, 176, 212]. Over time new agricultural practices and technologies have increased agricultural output, but have also led to increased costs and vulnerability for farmers during drought [ 83]. Given their occupational environment, agricultural workers are at increased risk of “silo-filler’s disease” (NO 2 gas poisoning within silos) [ 158]. Horticulturalists and people working for nurseries, garden supply stores and recreational facilities have also been identified as being at higher risk of negative health outcomes [ 46].
